Overview

Purpose
A customer will feel safe and secure when they are confident that a service technician can solve their problem. A gas technician/fitter must always maintain a professional attitude and use effective communication techniques when dealing with customers.

Objectives
At the end of this Chapter, you will be able to
• employ professional standards and behaviour; and
• use effective communication.

Terminology
- Active listening: Total listening ("listening" to both words and non-verbal communication)
- Effective communication: Clear communication (including non verbal)

Professional standards and behaviours

Attitude
A customer will feel safe and secure when they are confident that you can solve their problem. Your own confidence in your technical skills and knowledge, and a professional manner will increase a customer's sense of confidence and security.

The following will help you to project professionalism.

Do:
• Always show respect toward the customer
• Explain problems in an easy-to-understand way

Do not/never:
• Do not "speak down" to a customer

Everyone wants respect from other people. When dealing with customers, remember that a person being told about their faults, failures, and shortcomings can be hurtful and offensive. Treat your customers with the same respect that you would like to receive.

Remember that customers may not understand the technical aspects of your work. Explain the technical aspects in simple terms, and make sure you are not condescending in tone or explanation.

Example:
If a customer's thermostat needs to be adjusted or repaired, give a simple explanation of the thermostat's function and the problem.
1) First, note that the thermostat is a device that senses temperature changes and switches the furnace on and off to maintain the desired temperature in an area of the building.
2) Second, inform the customer, in terms that they can easily understand, about what needs be to adjusted or repaired.

Appearance
A neat, well-groomed appearance conveys to customers that your work is of high quality. To be professional, you must look professional.

Take note of the following:
• Uniforms and clothing should always fit well and be clean.
• Hair must be clean and well-groomed.
• Facial hair must be well-maintained. Neatly trim your beard or mustache if you have one.

Example:
A gas technician/fitter arrives at a customer's home unshowered, unshaven, wearing soiled, wrinkled clothing and dirty footwear. Most customers would understandably be concerned about the quality of work from someone who arrives in such a condition. An untidy appearance communicates a lack of self-respect as well as a lack of respect for the customer.

Workplace behaviour
As a representative of your company, you must always be aware of the impression you convey. Your behaviour while working on a customer's premises is an important part of your customer service responsibilities.

This list of dos and don'ts outlines the basic rules of workplace etiquette that all service technicians should abide by.

Do:
• Ask permission before you move furniture or other items.
• Alert the customer if you are going to cause a disturbance or make excessive noise.
• Ask permission before you use any utility (water, power, etc.).
• Clean up any mess or waste created by your work.

Do not/never:
• Do not wander about a customer's premises.
• Do not eat or smoke on a customer's premises.
• Do not help yourself to beverages.
• Do not disrupt the work of other personnel on the premises.
• Do not use a customer's telephone without permission.
• Do not leave equipment (or the premises) in disarray if you have to leave the building to get supplies or tools.
• Do not create hazards by leaving equipment or materials unattended.
• Do not leave tools or your toolbox on appliances (doing so may scratch the surface).

Unacceptable behaviour
Certain types of behaviour are always unacceptable when dealing with a customer and working on their property, including smoking, horseplay, harassment, profanity, and criticism of a customer's home or belongings.

When to refer to higher authority
At times, you may encounter questions from a customer which you cannot answer or which are beyond the scope of your authority. In these cases, refer the customer to a senior crew member (if present), or a supervisory staff member.

Some of these questions may be about
• non-technical matters;
• terms of a contract;
• terms of a warranty; or
• safety issues with installation.

Effective communication

Communication strategies
When listening to a customer's questions or concerns, use the following techniques to establish and maintain good communication.
• Maintain eye contact while talking and taking notes. This will help you to stay focused on what the customer is saying.
• If you are in a noisy or crowded environment, suggest moving to a quieter location so you can talk more easily.
• Avoid interrupting the customer. Be patient and allow the customer to finish speaking before you respond.
• Acknowledge the customer's concerns and be sympathetic about the problem or request.
• Ask for clarification, if necessary, so that the correct information is conveyed. Do not be afraid to ask for the relevant service manual. (It is impossible to retain all the specific information about every appliance — this is why manuals stay with appliances.)
• Take notes to share with supervisory staff and other relevant parties.
• Use layperson's terms, and ensure that the customer understands what you have said before you start talking about a new topic.
• Recap or summarize the customer's explanation of the problem or ask further questions to clarify your understanding.
• Ensure that the customer agrees to any corrective actions before you commence work.

First contact with a customer
As soon as you arrive at a customer's premises, determine what the problem is; to do so, ask why the customer called for service.

A good way to continue is to ask the customer to describe the problem. You need to know what the customer saw, heard, touched, or smelled that indicated a problem as well as when and where this occurred. Make sure to listen closely to their answers. Customers (or operators) can often lead you directly to the problem (which saves both of you time and money).

It is important to accurately determine what the problem is. If necessary, continue to ask questions until you have gathered all of the facts.

Example:
The best approach to a problem is to ask the right questions in the right way.

For example, Ms. McNeil called for furnace service, but there is no description of the problem or its symptoms on your service order.

Your first question to Ms. McNeil should be something like,
"Ms. McNeil, I understand that you have a problem with your furnace. Could you describe what kind of problem you are having?"

This kind of question is very useful for getting the information you need to understand the problem. Asking the right questions can make all the difference.

Instead of the question above, you could have asked,
"Ms. McNeil, I understand that you have a problem with your furnace. Could you please show me where the furnace is?"

If you had asked this question, although you would now know where to find the furnace, you would be no further ahead in terms of discovering what the actual problem is. Customer input is an important first step in troubleshooting problems: you get the information you need, and the customer is brought into the process. It is a win-win situation for all parties.

Informing the customer
Once you have identified (and solved) the problem, it is important to inform the customer — in terms they can easily understand — what the problem was and how it was resolved.

Maintaining a customer's sense of safety and security is an important part of customer relations. Fears and concerns are usually based on personal experience, and you should take them seriously — but also use the facts of the situation to alleviate a customer's fears and concerns. Most customers are not familiar with the technical aspects of the gas trade, so they depend on your expertise. A simple explanation goes a long way toward ensuring a customer's sense of well- being and comfort.

Example:
Unusual or loud noises, the smell of gas, and appliance failure can be very distressing for a customer.

Mr. Singh has placed an emergency call for service because his furnace is periodically making loud noises. You arrive on the scene and find Mr. Singh visibly distressed. The previous week, a suspected gas explosion destroyed a house in Mr. Singh's town.

After investigating the problem, you discover that the flame on the furnace pilot burner is too small. You change the pilot filter, adjust the pilot flame, test the ignition, and put the furnace back in operation, yet the customer is still fearful. In this situation, before you leave, make sure you assure the customer that the issue has been resolved and that there is no ongoing danger. The best way to do this is to give a brief, clear explanation of the problem, as shown below.

"Mr. Singh, I discovered that the pilot light on your furnace was not functioning properly. When this happens, the main burner does not light quickly, and there is delayed ignition. The pilot assembly was dirty, so I replaced it with a new, clean assembly. I have tested the furnace, and the ignition is now safe and reliable."

Through good communication and effective customer service, you will show yourself in a positive light, and the company you represent will reap the benefits in their bottom line.

Overview

Purpose
A customer's confidence (and your own professional image) is enhanced when you show respect for yourself and a customer's property. This Chapter outlines how a gas technician/fitter can act to prevent damage to property.

Objectives
At the end of this Chapter, you will be able to describe the ways a gas technician/fitter can act to prevent property damage.

Terminology
- Professionalism: Conducting yourself responsibly, with integrity and accountability; upholding excellent standards

Methods of preventing property damage

The following are some of the more basic ways to behave professionally and show respect for a customer's property.
• Properly park and secure your vehicle.
• Display professionalism through personal cleanliness.
• Use tools and equipment properly.
• Handle and install appliances properly.
• Use your own (not a customer's) tools and equipment.
• Clean up after you complete your work.

Parking and properly securing vehicles
One way to ensure good customer relations is by observing proper vehicle etiquette. Doing so also projects personal and corporate professionalism to the public as a whole.

Park service vehicles on the street, not in a customer's driveway. This is good practice for several reasons.

For example,
• street parking makes the vehicle more visible to the public, which is good advertising;
• street parking means there is no chance of you accidentally damaging toys, bicycles, or other objects in a driveway;
• street parking means oil or other spills from your vehicle will not damage a customer's property; and
• street parking means children are less likely to enter or damage your vehicle (especially because it is locked).

Displaying professionalism
Ensure that your hands and clothes are as clean as possible. Dirty hands and clothes not only present a poor image of both you and your company, they can also soil and damage a customer's premises and furnishings.

Dirty footwear can soil and damage carpets and floors. It is best to wear overshoes. Although it is common to take off footwear inside the home, safety boots are a part of personal protective equipment (PPE), so should not be removed.

Proper use of tools and equipment
Prevent damage to a customer's property by carefully handling tools and equipment. Follow the guidelines below.

Do:
• Use care and caution when carrying tools and equipment into and out of the premises.
• When necessary, use padding to protect floors, appliances, and furnishings.
• Keep a fire extinguisher close at hand when using a torch.

Do not/never:
• Do not place tools or equipment on a customer's appliances, furniture, or any other object or surface that may be damaged.
• Do not place magnetic flashlights or tools on a customer's appliance (or similar) as these can scratch metal surfaces.
• Do not unplug any of a customer's appliances to obtain power for your own purposes. In particular, do not unplug a refrigerator or freezer (as customers can claim damages in case of spoiled food).
• Do not leave a trouble light turned on when it is on the floor or near flammable materials. (A trouble light can overheat, cause fire, and discolour surfaces.)
• Do not leave burning torches unattended as these can easily tip over and cause fire.

Proper handling and installation of appliances
Before you install an appliance, take careful measurements to ensure that it will fit into the space provided and that there is adequate door, hall, and stairway clearance as well as space to manoeuvre. Adequate space will ensure ease of installation and reduce the possibility of damaging a customer's property.

Make an assessment of what needs to be done and devise a plan to complete the installation safely with no damage to equipment or the customer's property. You may need help from a colleague — some jobs, to complete safely, require two people.

When moving an appliance, you can do the following to prevent damage to walls and floors.
• Use protective pads.
• Use carts (with wheels) or dollies.
• Walk an appliance in small steps (rather than pushing or dragging it).
• Wrap the appliance in moving blankets.
• Use protective floor coverings.

Using a customer's tools or equipment
It is not acceptable to use a customer's tools or equipment. Indeed, doing so communicates unprofessionalism.

In addition, a customer's tools or equipment
• may be inferior quality, in poor condition, or unsuitable for the job;
• may break or malfunction (causing damage or personal injury that could result in an insurance claim or lawsuit); and
• may be lost or damaged in the course of doing your work (and need replacement).

Always use your own extension cords (certified for the task).

Do not unplug a customer's appliance (particularly a refrigerator or freezer) to use an outlet for your own purposes. However — if this is your only option — ask the customer for permission to do so. In these cases, it is a good idea to tie your extension cord to the customer's (unplugged) power cord. This will remind you to plug in the customer's appliance when you finish. (Doing so will also help to avoid potential insurance claims and lawsuits directed at you or your company.)

Cleaning up
It is necessary to clean up the area where you have been working.

A proper clean up involves
• cleaning up spills;
• only using solvents if they will not cause damage;
• removing and disposing of cleaning rags, cloths, etc.;
• cleaning up excess flux and solder after soldering; and
• removing all crating and packaging materials.

After you clean up, walk around and make sure you have not left any tools behind. You should aim to leave the area cleaner than it was when you arrived.

If an incident occurs that causes damage to a customer's property, immediately report it to the customer and your supervisor.

Note: Do not leave equipment or parts (such as parts of a furnace) behind. Doing so leaves you open to customers making damage claims.

topics: Dealing with different customer types (talkative, unresponsive, obstinate, whining, rude, suppressing anger, hostile, intoxicated)
chapters.content:
[Content for dealing with different customer types]

Option 1
One option is to reach agreement with the customer about the situation, i.e., you have a problem to solve and you can begin to solve it immediately. Ask them to show you the way to the furnace, thermostat, etc. This strategy ends the conversation with a practical question, in a way that continues to respect the dignity of the customer.

Option 2
Another option is to turn the topic of conversation towards the specific problem that the customer has asked you to solve then ask a question or make a statement that prompts action by the customer. This strategy should allow you to get on with the job without disrespecting the customer.

Example:
This example shows one method of dealing with a talkative customer. This customer, Mrs. Petrov, insists on talking to you excessively and is preventing you from working on the actual problem at hand.

In a case like this, you might say
"Mrs. Petrov, I understand that you have a problem with your furnace. You said that the house is not warming up to the temperature you set on the thermostat. I can solve that problem for you right now. Can you show me where the thermostat is located?"

This method ends the conversation by asking a practical question that asks for input from Mrs. Petrov while also respecting her dignity and allowing you to focus on your job.

The unresponsive customer
Some people are naturally shy and passive. If a customer is unresponsive and has little to say, you can try asking an "open-ended question" to get you the information you need. (An open-ended question is a question that requires a full answer — not just "yes" or "no".)

For example, you could ask one of the following.
"What problem are you experiencing?"
"How did this happen?"
"What can I do to help?"
"When did you notice the issue with your furnace?"

The obstinate customer
If a customer continues to be obstinate and uncooperative and you are having trouble coming to an agreement, make comments that are explicit about finding a solution.

The following are some possibilities.
"What would you like me to do now, [name of customer]?"
"What do you think would be a good way to solve this problem?"
"What can I do to make you happy?"

In response to such questions, a customer may be less demanding than you expect. However, if you still cannot reach agreement, you should seek the help of your supervisor.

The whining customer
Occasionally, you may encounter a "whining" customer — a person who tells other people all about their negative feelings, hurts, and disappointments. They may complain about how late you are or about how someone else in your company was rude to them. To respond to whining customers, you can ask the following questions.
"How could we have served you better?"
"How would you like things to be handled differently next time?"

Note: If you know you will arrive later than scheduled, you should call ahead or ask your dispatcher to. (If appropriate, inform the customer that you received an emergency call, which is of higher priority than a no-heat call.) Customers appreciate being "in the know". Calling ahead also means the customer gets a feel for who is coming to their home, which can lower their anxiety.

The rude customer
The main strategy to use when dealing with a rude customer is to "keep your cool". Smile in a friendly, inoffensive way and try asking one of the following questions.
"What would you like me to do to solve this problem?"
"I can see that I am not meeting your expectations. What can I do differently?"

The customer who is suppressing their anger
It is difficult to communicate with people who suppress ("bottle up") their anger. Although their words may not communicate their anger, their tone of their voice probably will. Before establishing meaningful communication with these customers, allow them to express their anger.

To do so, try the following.

Say "what you see".
"You are obviously very concerned about what has happened."
"You have every right to be upset about this."

Try to get the customer to talk about what is bothering them.
"How do you feel about this?"
"What was your reaction when this happened?"

After a customer has had the chance to express their anger, you can move on to questions that will allow you to proceed with solving their problem.

The hostile customer
You cannot communicate with a customer who is shouting. First, wait until they have calmed down. In the meantime, there are several things you can do to manage the situation.
• Listen actively and attentively, and let the customer continue until their anger has subsided.
• Maintain eye contact and a sympathetic facial expression.
• Use positive body language and an open, friendly posture.
• Always stay back at least 3 ft (1 m) so as not to violate a customer's personal space. This is especially true at the front door when you first make contact with a customer.
• When you speak, use phrases that communicate empathy, such as those beginning with, "Yes, I see".
• When circumstances allow, summarize what the customer expressed and restate the reason for their anger. Say, "Based on what you told me, this is what I understand". This will ensure that both you and the customer understand the situation.
• Identify the problem and try to maintain focus on it.
• When it becomes possible, move on to asking the customer questions that will allow you to get on with the job. For example, "What can I do to help solve this problem?"

The intoxicated customer or the customer who is using profane language
As a service technician, you should never accept a customer verbally abusing or being violent toward you. However, you may sometimes find yourself, unwittingly, in such a situation. If this occurs, you can use the following strategies.

If a customer is abusive, you can say the following statements.
"I am sorry, but if you cannot speak to me professionally. I will have to call my supervisor."
"I am sorry, but if you cannot speak to me professionally, I will have to leave."

In the immediate aftermath of such an incident, make accurate notes for future reference. If another worker was present and witnessed the incident, ask them to review (and sign) your notes about the incident.

Note: You must never accuse a customer of being intoxicated or under the influence of drugs. Such accusations can render you and your employer liable to legal action.

High-risk situations

Avoiding situations that put you at risk
Although you should never deliberately put yourself in risky situations, as a gas service technician, you may inadvertently find yourself in situations that put you at risk.

Indeed, the work of a gas technician/fitter affects others' basic survival. Answering a no-heat call on a cold evening puts you face-to-face with customers who are depending on your action and assistance for their family's safety and survival. Understanding a customer's level of anxiety up front may help defuse tension.

The following circumstances may put you at risk.
• Performing actions for which you could receive criticism (such as smoking or pretending to clean an-already clean furnace).
• Entering a home in which young children or minors are alone and without adult supervision.
• Being on a premises alone (without the presence of the customer or another representative).
• Interacting with a customer who is obviously under the influence of alcohol or another substance.
• Interacting with a customer who is abusive or unreasonable.

Dealing with violence
There may be occasions when an enraged customer confronts and threatens you or becomes violent. In such a situation, keep calm and find a way to leave the premises. If necessary, call 911.

Recognizing potentially dangerous customers
You can learn to recognize potentially violent customers by reading a person's body language and other non-verbal communication.

Specifically, look for signs, such as
• clenched fists and a tense body posture;
• a red face, tight lips, flared nostrils, wide-open eyes;
• an agitated and aggressive tone of voice; or
• evidence of alcohol or drug use.

If a customer does become unruly or threatens you with violence, immediately seek assistance. You do not have to put up with threats of any sort.

Never attempt to reason with a customer who is behaving in a threatening way, or who may be under the influence of alcohol or drugs. If there is a potential for violence, do not be embarrassed to call the police. It is better to risk embarrassment than to be a victim of violence.

Speak to your supervisor about what made you uncomfortable with this specific customer. Ask that their address be flagged and notes added indicating the risk — this is to ensure the safety of technicians who may attend calls at this address in the future. As a worker, you have a right to refuse unsafe work under occupational health and safety rules contained in OHSA, and your supervisor is aware of this right.

(Different in nature, but similar in effect, are customers who make unwanted advances such as complimenting you on your looks, asking you out on a date, or offering you a tip — behaviour that may make you feel uncomfortable and unwilling to be alone with them.)

Personal safety tips
Read the danger signs in your work environment.

Do:
• Ask your dispatcher to check company records if you suspect a customer has a history of being problematic or has a record of aggressive or violent behaviour.
• If you feel threatened, move to a safe location. If necessary, you can return later with your supervisor or the police.
• Immediately report all incidents of aggression or violence to your supervisor. Report all details in writing.
• Be more cautious at night, as criminal activity and personal crime increase sharply at night.

Do not/never:
• Do not allow any situation to distract you from paying attention to what is going on around you. Perform occasional checks to make sure you are not being stalked or followed.
• Do not make yourself an easy target for robbery. For example, do not openly flash cash or wear expensive jewelry.

assignment_questions.question: Match the customer expectations (1–4) to the descriptions of how to meet these expectations [a)–d)].
options: 1. Expectation to be listened to - a) Use effective listening techniques; assure the customer that you are being attentive to their problem
2. Expectation to have their problem taken seriously - b) Be respectful (not condescending) in your words and actions
3. Expectation to be treated with respect - c) Respond to the customer in a confident, serious, professional manner
4. Expectation to have their problem solved immediately - d) Solve the customer's problem as quickly as circumstances permit

assignment_questions.question: What should you do after you have solved a customer's problem and your work is complete?
options: a) Nothing
b) Leave immediately without further communication
c) Produce an invoice for the work and demand payment
d) Follow up with the customer to check that they are satisfied
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) Follow up with the customer to check that they are satisfied

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is the best choice of words when responding to a customer's complaint?
options: a) "You are overreacting."
b) "I can understand why you feel that way."
c) "It's not that bad."
d) "This is just part of the process."
assignment_questions.correct_answer: b) "I can understand why you feel that way."

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is a better choice of words than "You are not making any sense" when responding to a customer's concerns?
options: a) "That is definitely wrong."
b) "Maybe I am not understanding you correctly."
c) "You're way off base."
d) "Did you really say …?"
assignment_questions.correct_answer: b) "Maybe I am not understanding you correctly."

assignment_questions.question: What is the best strategy when engaged in an argument with a customer?
options: a) Listen actively and re-state what the customer is saying to you
b) Raise your voice to ensure you are heard
c) Remind the customer that you are the expert
d) Aim to avoid any arguments
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) Listen actively and re-state what the customer is saying to you

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following non-verbal communication techniques could you use to defuse a customer's anger?
options: a) Roll your eyes
b) Maintain a facial expression that is calm, sincere, concerned, and interested
c) Turn your back on the customer
d) Say nothing and leave without fixing the problem
assignment_questions.correct_answer: b) Maintain a facial expression that is calm, sincere, concerned, and interested

assignment_questions.question: What is an appropriate response to a customer who is demanding something unreasonable or impossible?
options: a) Calmly leave the location and note the behaviour on the work order
b) Calmly and patiently tell the customer what you can do (rather than what you cannot do)
c) Calmly explain alternative solutions or options that may meet the customer's needs
d) Calmly leave without saying anything
assignment_questions.correct_answer: b) Calmly and patiently tell the customer what you can do (rather than what you cannot do) OR c) Calmly explain alternative solutions or options that may meet the customer's needs

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is a poor response when dealing with a rude customer?
options: a) "Do you want this fixed, or not?"
b) "What would you like me to do to solve this problem?"
c) "I am not meeting your expectations. What can I do differently?"
d) "Let me try to understand your concern better, so we can find a solution."
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) "Do you want this fixed, or not?"

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is a good response to an abusive customer?
options: a) Say, "You are rude, and I do not have to take this abuse. I am leaving"
b) Argue with the customer and defend yourself
c) Say nothing and leave
d) Say, "I am sorry, but if you cannot speak to me professionally, I will have to leave"
assignment_questions.correct_answer: d) Say, "I am sorry, but if you cannot speak to me professionally, I will have to leave"

assignment_questions.question: What should you do if a customer becomes unruly or threatening?
options: a) Seek assistance and, if they threaten violence, call the police
b) Confront the customer and try to immediately resolve the situation
c) Shut off the fuel supply and mark on the work order that the system has been tagged
d) Turn off and lock the meter or fuel supply
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) Seek assistance and, if they threaten violence, call the police

3. Not displaying _______ body language or speaking to a customer in a condescending manner shows that you respect them. - c) Responding

Overview

Purpose
In our multicultural society, there are many occasions when a gas technician/fitter will encounter someone who has a different cultural background to their own. This Chapter outlines some cultural differences that a gas technician/fitter may encounter and some strategies to employ in these circumstances.

Objectives
At the end of this Chapter, you will be able to
• describe cultural differences; and
• describe strategies for overcoming cultural differences when they affect your work.

Terminology
- Cross culture: Interactions between members of different cultural groups
- Limited English proficiency: Individuals who do not speak English as their primary language and who have a limited ability to use and understand English

Cultural differences

Everyone — regardless of race, creed, or colour — deserves the same quality of service and treatment. In our multicultural society, there are many occasions when a service person will encounter someone of a different culture.

Here are some aspects of culture to keep in mind
• use of space and time;
• religious history and practice;
• values around work, property, family, and home;
• values and expectations about gender and individual behaviour; and
• clothing, food, and beverages.

Barriers to cross-cultural communication

Here are some potential barriers to positive cross-cultural communication
• difficulty communicating due to language differences;
• misinterpretation of non-verbal communication and body language;
• lack of cultural awareness and ethnocentrism (only seeing the world from the perspective of your own culture);
• different cultural norms and expectations or different value systems; and
• stereotyping.

Overcoming barriers to achieve positive cross-cultural communication

Common misconceptions about specific cultures can create challenges in cross-cultural communication. It is important to be able to identify mistaken perceptions and assumptions about other cultures in order to counter them. Communication with people from other cultures in conjunction with tolerance and understanding can go a long way toward overcoming cross-cultural barriers.

It is a good idea to read up on some of the different cultures you may encounter so you can have a better understanding of the cultural differences of people you will meet.

Dealing with customers who have limited English proficiency

One common problem when dealing with people of different cultures is the use of different languages.

However, you can improve communication with customers who speak little or no English by doing the following.
• Learn a few phrases of their language.
• Use a translation app or website.
• Identify those among your staff who speak different languages, and who could, therefore, help you. (You could even put their names on an easy-to-access list for quick referral.)
• Practice slowing down your speech (but refrain from speaking more loudly).
• Learn and use the customer's name. "Mr. or Ms. [name], I know that you speak more than one language but, unfortunately, I only speak English. I want to help you ..."
• If you are communicating face-to-face, you can ask the customer to write their name and request. (After all, there are no accents to contend with in the written word.)

Overcoming cultural differences that can affect work

Cultural differences and work
Some possible cultural differences that may affect your work include
• timelines and scheduling;
• contractual details and consent;
• payment terms and procedures;
• expectations regarding service; and
• access to a person's property.

Suggested strategies to accommodate cultural differences
You may need to implement the following strategies in these circumstances.
• Adjust work schedules to respect religious or cultural practices.
• Make extra effort to explain your work and what the customer can expect.
• Explain company policies and procedures and confirm agreement before you begin work.
• Use an interpreter to resolve any misunderstandings. (Many customers will have a family member who speaks English.)
• Acknowledge and observe rules of appropriate behaviour with respect to a customer's home or place of business. For example, do not use dismissive language or display looks of disgust to a customer.
• In all cases, it is best to remain patient and polite. It also never hurts to pepper your communication with "please" and "thank you". Common courtesy can go a long way toward smoothing out challenges in customer relations.
• Always aim to keep your words and communication simple: avoid technical jargon and complicated sentence structures. Just say what you mean as clearly and simply as possible.
• When it is not clear to you what the other person is saying, seek clarification. Summarizing or paraphrasing can be really helpful in checking that you correctly understand what the other person has said. Try rephrasing their words and adding a simple question at the end.

assignment_questions.question: Which is the best strategy for communicating with a customer who speaks only a little English?
options: a) Speaking more slowly
b) Speaking more loudly
c) Speaking more loudly and more slowly
assignment_questions.correct_answer: a) Speaking more slowly

assignment_questions.question: Which of the following is good strategy when you are communicating with a customer whose English is heavily accented?
options: a) Inform the customer that someone else will help them instead of you
b) Ask the customer to write down their name and the information they want to communicate to you
c) Use visual aids or gestures to communicate with the customer
d) Point and speak loudly
assignment_questions.correct_answer: b) Ask the customer to write down their name and the information they want to communicate to you OR c) Use visual aids or gestures to communicate with the customer

assignment_questions.question: How can cultural differences affect your work schedule?
options: a) Someone who has the same cultural background as the customer will need to attend
b) Cultural differences do not affect work schedules in any way
c) Work may have to be scheduled around religious or cultural practices
assignment_questions.correct_answer: c) Work may have to be scheduled around religious or cultural practices
